content.body: I know this is a very very old topic. Whatever happens to const parameters? function f(const a){}. I might need that as an assumption to one of my ideas, but was it not possible? It seems straightforward, but I feel like I'm missing some technical issue perhaps that stopped it from being put in when const was.
content.org.matrix.msc1767.text: I know this is a very very old topic. Whatever happens to const parameters? function f(const a){}. I might need that as an assumption to one of my ideas, but was it not possible? It seems straightforward, but I feel like I'm missing some technical issue perhaps that stopped it from being put in when const was.

content.body: I sometimes like it, but it really isn't easy to encourage people to use it.

content.body:
Question about Annex B.3.4 (https://tc39.es/ecma262/#sec-variablestatements-in-catch-blocks):

Why does the text before the note only modify `var`, while the text after the note also modifies `function`?

content.body: Is that section only changing the semantics for function declarations in eval, or also outside of eval?
i think in practice it's for both
content.org.matrix.msc1767.text: i think in practice it's for both

content.body: wouldn't function declarations outside of direct evals already be covered by LexicallyDeclaredNames?
content.org.matrix.msc1767.text: wouldn't function declarations outside of direct evals already be covered by LexicallyDeclaredNames?

content.body: but function declarations inside direct evals need special handling because top-level function declarations in direct evals only introduce var bindings in the outside scope in B.3.2 semantics anyway... or something like that?
content.org.matrix.msc1767.text: but function declarations inside direct evals need special handling because top-level function declarations in direct evals only introduce var bindings in the outside scope in B.3.2 semantics anyway... or something like that?

content.body: Oh because 11.b of functions in eval ("If replacing the FunctionDeclaration f with a VariableStatement that has F as a BindingIdentifier would not produce any Early Errors for body, then") never produces an early error, so it's different from non-eval functions...
content.formatted_body: Oh because 11.b of functions in eval ("If replacing the FunctionDeclaration f with a VariableStatement that has F as a BindingIdentifier would not produce any Early Errors for body, then") never produces an early error, so it's different from non-eval functions...
